climbs.name: Vault 7
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, 12/17; FFA: Zack Slinskey? Matt Samet?

content.description:
This is a tough little route to the right of

Tiger Swan

. Scramble up to the first bolt, then continue up the strenuous and flaring crack with poor feet. One more bolt and a difficult section leads to the anchor. This can be toproped easily after climbing

Tiger Swan

. Although graded easier, this climb is a harder tick than

Tiger Swan

in my opinion.
content.protection: 2 bolts, small cams, and nuts to about fingers/thin hands size.
content.location:
This is just right of

Tiger Swan

and is currently the farthest right route on the wall.

climbs.name: Tiger Swan
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson - Sept. 2017 (5.12 A0). F.F.A.: Angus Wiessner on Oct. 5, 2017

content.description: This climb follows a left-facing flake & thin crack. Climb easy terrain up a wide crack for 15 feet to a big ledge & the 1st bolt. Reach the right side of an expanding flake, & move up left. Follow a fun lieback flake/crack that turns into a difficult shallow, thin crack. Moderate 5.10 climbing abruptly gets very difficult at the 6th bolt. Two crux sequences with tip jams, gastons & rounded lieback holds lead past the last 2 bolts. Reach a horizontal thin crack on the right. Move up left along the crack to a jug, & clip the anchor bolts.
content.location:
This is 15 feet right of

The Monkey Wrench

.

content.description:
This route starts about 10 feet to the right of '

Living With the Apes

,' and starts by climbing up a flaring crack.  This is followed by tricky slab climbing for the remainder of the route.  The technical crux is down low, but be careful of that last move!  '

Living With the Apes

' and this route both share anchors.
content.protection: 9 quickdraws, and a 50m rope.  There is a two bolt anchor at the top.

content.description: The third and final route on The Zoo, this one lies near the right edge of the wall.  A big dyno down low is the crux (obviously easier if you're tall), and then easy terrain leads to a tricky thin section at the top.

This is the leftmost bolted route on The Zoo rock.  Although the cliff does extend for a little ways to the left of this route, it is approximately in the middle of the cliff.  Look for the bolts leading up just to the left of a small dihedral.   The moves on this route are consistently difficult.  There are two cruxes, and both of them are well protected.  This route is significantly harder if the quickdraws are not already hung. Unless you are very tall, expect some difficulties reaching the bolts when hanging the 'draws.  Aside from being poorly bolted (don't worry, it's still well protected, it's just that every bolt seems to be about 6 inches out of reach), this is a pretty good route.  Practice up on your slab technique, though.
content.protection: 10 quickdraws and something for the anchor. A 50m rope will be enough to get you down.

climbs.name: Greenwashing
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, Zack Slinskey, & Matt Wagner, July 15, 2017

content.description: This route ascends a face with a discontinuous, thin crack. Climb a short corner for a couple moves to a bulge. Step left around the bulge, & follow good holds past 2 bolts to gain the crack to the left. Ascend the crack (.11a) with good gear placements to its end. A final crux moves onto a slab past the 3rd bolt. Step right to a ledge. Continue up left to the anchor bolts.
content.protection: 3 bolts; #6-7 stoppers; a blue, two green, and a red Aliens; and 2 rings.
content.location:
It climbs the obvious face with thin crack 20 feet left of

Living With The Apes

.
